headline: CDC vaccine committee overturns decades-old hepatitis B recommendation for newborns
summary: The CDC's Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices voted 8-3 to eliminate its 1991 universal recommendation that all newborns receive hepatitis B vaccine within 24 hours of birth, shifting instead to "individual-based decision-making" with a suggested delay until at least two months old while maintaining the recommendation for infants born to infected mothers and preserving coverage through Medicaid and the Vaccines for Children program, a change that may affect insurance reimbursement and mirrors recent COVID-19 vaccine guideline revisions.

headline: Bring dad home: Great Falls man arrested by ICE may have to leave daughter, pregnant fiancé
summary: ICE agents arrested 26-year-old visa overstayer Dakota Wheeler in Great Falls on Nov. 13 using unmarked vehicles and without clear identification; he is detained at Cascade County Jail under a federal marshal contract permitting extended immigration holds. The facility depends on federal contracts for 70% of its $14 million annual budget, generating $82-$115 per detainee daily. Sheriff Jesse Slaughter stated the county unsuccessfully sought a separate ICE contract for increased revenue, describing federal detainees as critical to funding operations. A federal judge granted a restraining order preventing Wheeler's removal from Montana and ensuring his access to counsel pending his Dec. 10 hearing.

headline: SC sees ‘alarming’ increase in measles cases, with 280 in quarantine
summary: The South Carolina Department of Public Health is managing a measles outbreak in the Upstate region with 84 cases and over 280 people in quarantine across eight schools. Governor Henry McMaster stated the state will not mandate vaccinations or quarantines but warned measles can be deadly. Vaccination rates at affected schools range from 81% to 95.9%, with 77 of 84 infected individuals being unvaccinated. Health officials opened a pop-up mobile vaccine clinic in Boiling Springs and are concerned about post-holiday case increases. Officials also worry about potential quarantine violations that could further spread the highly contagious disease.

headline: Mingo County residents file federal lawsuit against company building power plants, data center in WV
summary: Mingo and Logan County residents have opposed the Adams Fork Energy Project through public hearings and sustained pushback against state DEP-issued air quality permits; this community opposition to the ammonia and natural gas power plants over health and environmental concerns could escalate into organized protests or civil unrest if federal courts do not intervene to require additional environmental reviews.

headline: U.S. Supreme Court hears case from Mississippi preacher over city of Brandon’s protest restrictions
summary: A Mississippi preacher was convicted under a Brandon city ordinance restricting protests to designated areas after demonstrating outside a concert venue with graphic signs and a loudspeaker. The U.S. Supreme Court is weighing whether his no-contest plea bars him from challenging the ordinance under Heck v. Humphrey precedent. The city defends its regulation as content-neutral, aimed at preventing disturbances from insults rather than suppressing speech. The case could set precedent for municipal protest regulations and limit constitutional challenges from convicted protesters. Lower courts sided with the city; a Supreme Court ruling is expected this summer.

headline: Rural Kansas hospital missed out on $2 million in taxpayer funds that went to cities instead
summary: For nine years, the Kansas Department of Revenue misdirected nearly $2 million in voter-approved sales tax revenue from Morton County Hospital to three cities due to a ballot citation error, severely underfunding the rural facility that struggles with staff recruitment, Medicaid cuts, and thin margins. The Attorney General affirmed the hospital's right to full funding, and monthly payments have since doubled to $36,000. However, a legislative committee refused to order state reimbursement, instead delaying the issue to the 2026 session, leaving the hospital's financial recovery uncertain.

headline: Wichita State University president preparing campus for budget cuts, staff reductions
summary: The Kansas Board of Regents submitted a reduced budget request to the 2026 Legislature due to political pressure to limit state expenditures, signaling another tight budget year for Kansas universities as state funding fails to keep pace with rising operational costs, prompting Wichita State University to implement a minimum 3% budget reduction with likely staff dismissals and the University of Kansas to plan $71 million in combined cuts across its Lawrence and medical center campuses.

headline: US vaccine advisers say not all babies need a hepatitis B shot at birth
summary: A federal vaccine advisory committee appointed by U.S. Health Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. voted to end the universal recommendation that all newborns receive hepatitis B vaccine at birth, restricting it to high-risk infants despite opposition from medical and public health leaders. The policy shift reverses three decades of disease prevention strategy that has significantly reduced pediatric hepatitis B cases and prevented thousands of illnesses, with critics arguing the committee has abandoned evidence-based public health principles. Committee members questioned past vaccine safety data and cited low infection risk for most infants, while public health experts warn the change could increase chronic infection, liver cancer, and cirrhosis rates. The decision reflects a broader move away from population-level disease prevention toward individual risk assessment, with the committee now excluding CDC scientists from presenting safety data and elevating anti-vaccine voices. Acting CDC Director Jim O'Neill will decide whether to adopt the recommendation, which public health advocates have condemned as transforming a once-authoritative scientific body into what they call an "epidemiological crime scene."

headline: Still no contract for NM ICE lockup, as detainees report interrupted access to ‘vital’ tablets
summary: The inter-governmental services agreement for the Torrance County immigrant detention facility expired October 31, 2025, yet ICE continues detaining approximately 550 immigrants without a renewed contract, prompting U.S. Senator Martin Heinrich to demand immediate detainee transfers and question the agency's legal authority. Despite the contract lapse during the federal shutdown and its reopening November 13, Torrance County officials report receiving no updates from ICE or private operator CoreCivic on renewal terms. Detainees have submitted handwritten complaints about persistent poor conditions, specifically citing tablet failures that block access to legal resources, medical care requests, and external communication. CoreCivic maintains it provides safe and humane care and is unaware of significant tablet issues, while ICE has not responded to inquiries from officials or the senator. The situation raises policy concerns about ICE's compliance with its own standard operating procedures requiring detainee removal when contracts expire and ongoing accountability issues at a facility previously recommended for closure by federal inspectors.

headline: ‘We may be deporting the wrong people’: New poll shows doubts about immigration crackdown
summary: A new Goodwin Simon Strategic Research poll commissioned by pro‑immigrant groups found broad bipartisan support among California voters for due‑process protections for immigrants with criminal convictions, with 84% of Democrats, 61% of independents and 54% of Republicans agreeing that individuals deserve a hearing before deportation. The survey also revealed that 61% of voters want California’s prison system to stop directly handing immigrants over to ICE, and that state prisons have transferred more than 9,500 people to ICE since 2019. After hearing personal narratives of rehabilitation, support for judicial review increased among Democrats and independents but dropped slightly among Republicans (54% to 51%). The poll reflects waning support for the Trump administration’s expedited‑removal policies and suggests that detailed personal stories can shift public opinion on immigration enforcement. California’s sanctuary law does not cover serious crimes, yet the findings indicate voter appetite for limiting state‑federal cooperation even for those with records.

headline: Shapiro Budget Secretary Uri Monson stepping down to lead PSERS
summary: State Budget Secretary Uri Monson is leaving for PSERS, with Deputy Secretary Zachary Reber succeeding him; Monson's tenure featured three budget cycles with a divided legislature, Pennsylvania's first debt management plan, and a bond refinancing saving $193 million.

headline: As KY Republicans mull income tax cut, Beshear warns against crashing fiscal guardrails
summary: Kentucky faces a projected $300+ million revenue shortfall for the current fiscal year, with flat revenue growth failing to keep pace with rising costs, including a new $180 million state burden for SNAP administration. The Consensus Forecasting Group attributes the shortfall partly to decreased income tax revenue from rate cuts that have already reduced the rate from 5% to 3.5%. Governor Beshear warns that costs are rising significantly faster than revenues, potentially straining state services, while Republican lawmakers debate further income tax cuts for 2026 despite missing fiscal triggers established in 2022 law. The triggers were designed to prevent a budget crisis by ensuring revenue adequacy before each rate reduction. This creates a political conflict over whether to adhere to the guardrails or proceed with cuts that could worsen the structural deficit.

headline: Murrill: State won’t use Louisiana law against obstructing immigration raids to target speech
summary: Louisiana's Act 399 (2025) threatens up to $5,000 fines and one-year imprisonment for interfering with federal immigration enforcement, prompting an ACLU lawsuit over First Amendment concerns regarding "know-your-rights" trainings; the Attorney General clarified the law targets violent obstruction, not speech, amid "Operation Catahoula Crunch," and a federal judge acknowledged an agreement that the statute won't be applied to violate constitutional rights.

headline: Restaurant industry in New Orleans braces for immigration sweep
summary: DHS launched a two-month immigration enforcement operation in Louisiana and Mississippi targeting "criminal illegal aliens" with 250 agents aiming to arrest 5,000 people, creating widespread unease in New Orleans' hospitality sector which relies heavily on immigrant workers; restaurants are preparing by posting signs, establishing protocols, and seeking guidance from the Immigrant Legal Resource Center and Louisiana Restaurant Association, while at least one business has temporarily closed, and industry groups note that ICE can enter public areas without warrants but require judicial warrants for back-of-house spaces and will likely request I-9 employment verification forms.

headline: Dr. Ashish Jha, a familiar face during COVID pandemic, stepping down as Brown’s public health dean
summary: Dr. Ashish Jha will depart Brown University's School of Public Health in December to spearhead a national pandemic preparedness initiative, following his role as White House COVID-19 Response Coordinator; his exit occurs amid Health and Human Services Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr.'s push to revise infant hepatitis B vaccine guidance and curtail COVID-19 vaccine recommendations, which led a CDC committee to delay its vote on the hepatitis policy until Friday.

outlet: News From The States - Fair. Fearless. Free.
headline: Retiring US Sen. Durbin makes last push for long-stalled immigration bill
summary: Sen. Dick Durbin reintroduced the Dream Act for the last time before his retirement, seeking to protect immigrant youth as the Trump administration's mass deportation campaign has detained dozens of DACA recipients despite their legal status. The 5th Circuit Court upheld deportation protections but found DACA's work authorization unlawful in Texas, leaving recipients in limbo. Durbin condemned masked federal agents in Chicago for sowing fear in immigrant communities. Younger Senate Democrats pledged to continue the legislative effort, though congressional passage remains unlikely. The bill represents Durbin's final push for immigration reform after decades of advocacy.

headline: U.S. Rep. Shri Thanedar introduces articles of impeachment against Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth
summary: Rep. Shri Thanedar introduced articles of impeachment against Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth for alleged murder conspiracy and reckless mishandling of classified war plans, which could generate public protests and civil unrest due to the grave war crimes accusations against a sitting cabinet member. The charges follow reports that Hegseth ordered military personnel to "kill everybody" on a civilian drug boat and leaked sensitive operation details in a Signal chat. House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries predicted Republicans would block any vote, highlighting the partisan nature of the effort. Thanedar previously abandoned Trump impeachment articles after Democratic leadership opposition. The impeachment proceedings may catalyze demonstrations concerning military accountability and executive power.

headline: NC Board of Education focuses on teacher pay amid competing funding priorities
summary: The North Carolina State Board of Education is prioritizing teacher pay and critical K-12 funding for the 2026 legislative short session amid warnings of "very limited revenue" and potential budget delays. North Carolina ranks 43rd nationally in teacher pay at $58,292, nearly $14,000 below the national average. The General Assembly failed to pass a 2025-26 budget, leaving educators without across-the-board raises despite proposals ranging from 2.3% to 10.6%. The state also faces a $13 billion school infrastructure backlog and shortages of mental health staff. DPI will present a narrowed strategic proposal to the board early next year.

headline: Brattleboro hospital projects $14.5M shortfall in current budget
summary: Brattleboro Memorial Hospital, the main healthcare provider for 55,000 people in southeastern Vermont, projects a $14.5 million operating loss for its current budget, prompting state regulators at Vermont's Green Mountain Care Board to order a recalculation under a new law that allows state intervention. The 61-bed facility has implemented a hiring freeze, dismissed six administrators, and is led by two acting co-CEOs who are physicians—orthopaedic surgeon Elizabeth McLarney and primary care physician Tony Blofson—after its previous CEO departed. The hospital attributes losses to unpaid patient bills, rising staff health insurance costs, and $5 million in reductions from federal and state pharmaceutical price and payment changes. Regulators have confirmed the $14.5 million projection as "an accurate representation" while the facility seeks new leadership and outside financial consulting. This financial instability threatens patient access to care in a region where the hospital is one of the largest employers and sole major provider.
